entry.title: Comment 1
entry.content: Is Firefox 3.5.2 ok to use anonymously with the current Tor/Vidalia package?

entry.title: Comment 2
entry.content:
I have the very same question. I am using 3.5.x now and it seems to be working OK. TorButton passes the proxy tests and I seem to be anonymous even when executing some "hard" benchmarks on the internet like http://www.cyscape.com/showbrow.aspx?bhcp=1 which in some older FF versions was able to see my timezone!!!

But I would like to hear some words from the devs on this. Is FF 3.5.x OK?

Thank you very much.

entry.title: Comment 3
entry.content: We're tackling FF3.5.x and torbutton over the next few weeks. Firefox 3.5.x has been described as "taking a shotgun to the codebase" from people reading the source. Expect to see a new torbutton that addresses many of the issues we find in the next month or so.

entry.title: Comment 4
entry.content: connections with the latest build are a ton more stable and connections seem 2-3x faster. nice job!

entry.title: Comment 5
entry.content: Recently,It's hard to build tor circuit successfully in China.

entry.title: Comment 6
entry.content:
As in, just letting the Tor client idle, does it build circuits at all?

I'm able to exit and extend circuits from nodes in china without an issue.

entry.title: Comment 7
entry.content:
Hi there,

please keep an "classic" Tor Browser Bundle with the Firefox 3.0.x versions, because the new Firefox 3.5.x versions are slower on my computer.

My PC is old, 6 years, 1,4 GHz AMD CPU with only MMX and 3DNow, no SSE opcodes support, 512 MB of RAM, etc.

Firefox 3.0.13 for example, runs faster and more smooth/fluent than Fx 3.5.x, here.

So for people with no money and/or old PCs, you should keep old versions, besides the newer ones, thx.

regards,

iNsuRRecTiON

entry.title: Comment 8
entry.content: We're not planning on switching TBB to Firefox 3.5.x anytime soon. FF 3.5.x needs a detailed code audit and thoughts about how to effectively mitigate anonymity and privacy leaks with Torbutton.
